chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we need to solve for the arithmetic and geometric averages of the given rates of return. .

Simplifying the equation we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Arithmetic average}&=\dfrac{61}{6}\\[15 pt]
&=10.17
\end{aligned}$$

The arithmetic average return is $10.17\%$

To solve for the geometric return, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Geometric average}&=[(1+x_1)\times (1+x_2) \times (1+x_n)]^\frac{1}{n}-1
\end{aligned}$$

Where $x_n$ refers to the nth term and n refers to the number of years.

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Geometric average}&=[(1+0.08)\times (1+0.26)\times(1+0.14)\\
&\times(1-0.17)\times (1+0.31)\times(1-0.01)]^{\frac{1}{6}}-1
\end{aligned}$$

Simplifying the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Geometric average}&=1.03255-1\\[15 pt]
&=0.03255
\end{aligned}$$

The geometric average is $3.255\%$
